trustfund:
TF035479-MOROCCO - EXPORT AND
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF035586-MOROCCO - FISHERIES PROJECT AND
            GENERAL SECTOR WORKS

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the Pilot Fisheries
            Development Project are as follows: project outcome is
            unsatisfactory; sustainability is likely; institutional
            development impact is modest; Bank performance is
            satisfactory; and Borrower performance is unsatisfactory.
            The ICR process for this project included a Beneficiary
            Survey and two Stakeholder Workshops. The key lessons are
            divided into those learned for the fisheries sector in
            general, those learned for the future of Moroccan fisheries,
            and those learned for future Bank interventions.  Lessons
            learned for fisheries include the following:  The most
            important lesson is that reform in the fisheries sector is a
            long-term affair.  A related lesson is that the Bank can
            play a key catalytic role in a fisheries sector at a time
            when government and the industry are trying to develop new
            paths of cooperation in sector management. A third lesson is
            that where a high rent sector like fisheries is concerned,
            the pressures are enormous, fiscal policy is key, and policy
            and institutional arrangements have to be absolutely clear
            if rent seeking behavior is not to lead to over investment
            and to over-extraction. A fourth and related lesson is that
            management must be accompanied by good monitoring. A clear
            message was key sector services such as fisheries research
            and stock assessment tend to be shunted aside by rent
            seeking behavior unless governance is transparent and
            mechanisms are in place to ensure that they are properly
            financed and fed into transparent management decisions. A
            strong management system may be based either on strong
            Government regulation or on an industry-managed
            self-regulatory system but management depends on the
            existence of strong monitoring capability. The Stakeholder
            Workshop in Rabat emphasized that policy on rent extraction
            has to be backed up by fiscal recovery mechanisms that are
            recognized as efficient and equitable. Lessons learned for
            the future of Moroccan fisheries touched on the need for the
            gender unit to be confirmed in the management structure and
            have a regular line budget of its own; highlighted the role
            of fishermen in pointing out the risk of over fishing and
            calling for management and monitoring that increased
            quality, not quantity; confirmed that the Good Practice
            Guides are powerful tools for promoting environmental
            awareness among stakeholders; and noted that the project
            format was seen as too cumbersome, the procurement and
            consultant management tasks too slow and ponderous so that
            the Bank and Morocco should form a strategic partnership.
            General lessons for Bank interventions note that where a
            project is a broad-ranging pilot, flexibility should be
            built in, but there should be rules for agreeing and
            implementing adaptations to the original design; and that
            the project proved a valuable transition instrument in this
            sector because sector stakeholders placed a high value on
            this project-although it was small and perhaps relatively
            negligible in the eyes of the Government or the Bank.
